loans.name: Susanna

texts.en: Susanna started her fish sales 20 years ago in the community where she lives. She takes delivery of fish from the Kumasi and Yeji. She believes this will help her get affordable prices. Susanna has a store in the community market where she sells the fish. Her smoked fish tastes very good, attracting customer to buy from her stand. She has a high customer base that (customers) travels from the surrounding communities to buy her fish. They buy from her both the fresh ones and the smoked ones. She is now 45 years old, married and the mother of seven children. Currently six are in school and one is learning hairdressing. She requests the loan to upgrade her stock of fish to upgrade her inventory. Susanna belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame neme Boafo’ which means God is my helper.

loans.use: To buy more stock

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi is 38 years old. She is married and the mother of six children. All her children are currently in school.  She is a trader and trades in clothing materials, blouses and skirts, women's underwear and slippers. Esi has been in business for six years now; this has given her a rich experience in sales and marketing. But her problem has to do with inadequate funds to upgrade her business. She sells through hawking in the community and other surrounding villages during their market days. Demand for her products is on the higher side and she is not able to purchase high quality products. She believes the loan will help her to be more resourced to purchase good quality and large quantity to scale up sales. She wants to use the loan to purchase clothing materials, ladies wear and slippers to increase her inventory. She belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame nsa wom’ which literary means God has a hand in it.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing to sell

loans.name: Sonia Del Carmen

texts.es: La Señora Sonia del Carmen S. tiene la edad de 51 años, Es una mujer casada. Tiene 2 hijos a su cargo y estudian. La actividad económica de Sonia es la venta de cosméticos. Hace más de 6 años que se dedica a este negocio. Anteriormente se dedicaba a la venta de mercadería en general, pero debido a la situación económica que enfrentaba era muy difícil visitar a sus clientes y al mismo tiempo mantener a sus hijos, por lo que empezó a dedicarse a la venta de cosméticos. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para capital de trabajo para la compra de pinturas de labios, pinturas de uña entre otras coas. El deseo de Sonia es de mejorar el servicio brindado para sus clientes.
texts.en:
Señora Sonia del Carmen S. is 51 years old. She is married, and has 2 children who are in school. Sonia's business is the sale of cosmetics. She has been in this business for more than 6 years. Before, she was involved in the sale of general merchandise, but due to the economic situation she faced, it became very difficult to visit her customers and also take care of her children. Therefore, she began to dedicate herself to the sale of cosmetics. This loan request is for working capital for the purchase of lipstick, nail polish and other items. Sonia's desire is to improve the service she provides for her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys is 51 years old. She is married and a mother with four children. Currently three are schooling and the eldest is working. They are a very humble family who wants to invest in their children's future by providing them with a quality education. She lives at Sefwi in the western region of Ghana. She is a petty trader and sells items like cooking oil, spices, pepper, onions, smoked and dried fish, tinned tomatoes, bags of rice etc. Selling of these products, she says, they move very fast and you can easily recover your money. She takes delivery of goods from the capital city of Kumasi. With her four years experience in her business she wants to add other stuff like maize, eggs and others, which are frequently demanded by her customers. She believes that this can be possible with the help of a loan. Therefore, she wants the loan to buy more bags of raw materials like rice, spices, tin tomatoes etc. She is much convinced that the loan will help her increase her stock in the event of a price hike. And also she believes this would give her more to save towards her kid’s education. She says she would be grateful for your assistance. She belongs to a village bank called ‘Nyame ne boafo’ which means ‘God is my helper’.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama T. started selling fish five years ago in Sefwi in the western region of Ghana, where she lives. Ama prepares and serves very tasty and good quality fish and because of that, many customers buy from her stand. 

She is 26 years old and married with three children, including twins. One is currently schooling while the twins are breastfeeding. She wants to use the loan to buy more stock of assorted fish to increase her sales and income, which will support her children’s education and business growth. She would be grateful for the assistance.

loans.use: To buy more stock of smoked fishes

loans.name: Fight For Shameness Group

texts.en:
This is Isatu K., Sallay K. and Betty K.. They named their group Fight for Shameness. They are local entrepreneurs based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. This is not the first loan these women have received from SMT/Kiva. Previous loans have made a significant impact on the lives of these borrowers. They were able to feed their children, send them to school and meet most of their daily financial challenges from the proceeds they make from their businesses. Having repaid their last loan successfully, they have now applied again for a new loan to further strengthen their businesses.

Isatu K. (right) is the leader of this group. Isatu was born in Boya Romendey, in northern Sierra Leone. She is now 45 and married with four children. Two of her children are in secondary schools and two are in primary schools. Her husband in an architect and both of them work hand in hand in running the home. Isatu sells both dried and fresh fish. She has been in this business for many years. Occasionally, Isatu also sells cakes.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica, 32, is married and the mother of four children who are currently in school. She operates a shop and sells all kinds of clothing for men and women, like blouses, skirts, slippers, dressing bags, jeans, trousers, etc. She sells in the various communities during their market days. She sometimes sells through hawking and has been trading for the past 13 years. 

It is her desire to provide a quality education for her children to secure them a better future. Monica is constrained by funds in running the business. She needs the loan to inject more working capital into the business to boost her progress. She believes the loan will help her purchase a large quantity of good quality items to upgrade her inventory. She says she would be grateful for that assistance. Mary belongs to a village bank called "Nkunimdie," which means success.

loans.use: To purchase dresses, slippers, dressing bags, etc.

loans.name: Mavis

texts.en:
Mavis is 36 years old, married and the mother of four kids.  Currently, all her children are in school in the community where they live.  Her husband is very supportive, but not enough to achieve her desired business target.  She is a food vendor and sells kenkey with fried fish through hawking.  Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked and eaten with hot pepper and fried fish.  She has many customers since many Ghanaians enjoy kenkey as breakfast, lunch and supper. 

She wants to use this loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to increase her savings to support her children's education. She belongs to the community group called ‘Ebenezer Nti’.  In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia is 28 years old, single and has no children.  She dropped out of school due to lack of financial support.  She decided to learn a trade in order to earn a living.  She now runs a clothing shop and sells ladies and children wears like blouses, skirts, batik tie and dye, lingerie, underwear, slippers, and drinking water in sachets.  She has been selling her merchandise in a small kiosk in the community market where she lives.  She has insufficient working capital to run the business.  

With the loan, she wants to inject more working capital into the business to scale up business progress.  She believes the loan will enable her to purchase quality goods in large quantities to upgrade her inventory.  She says she would be grateful to lenders for that assistance.  She belongs to the community group called ‘Ebenezer Nit’.  In this group, members guarantee and support one another to repay their loans.

loans.use: To purchase lingerie, underwear, dressing bags and slippers

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora is thirty five (35) years old.  She is married and has been blessed with one child.  She is resourceful and enterprising.  She attended vocational school, but she could not complete her program for lack of adequate funds.  She later married a man and gave birth to a child.  It is her dream to continue her vocational program in cooking to add value to herself.  She operates a local restaurant and sells local food like “fufu”.  Fufu is prepared from pounding cassava and plantain and is eaten with soup, together with any kind of fish or meat.  She says prices of raw materials have gone up significantly, and she is no longer able to meet her production expenditures.  

She needs the loan to inject additional capital into the business in order to scale up production and maintain quality.  She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.  Dora is a member of a group called ‘Success.'

loans.use: To buy more baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul K. is a 45-year-old man. He is married and has five children. All his kids are in school. He lives with his wife in his matrimonial home, at Sefwi in the western region of Ghana. He is an achiever and a resourceful young man. He loves selling goods, the business through which he makes a living. 

Paul has been trading in crates of eggs in the community market for eight years now. He treks to surrounding villages in the Ashanti region of Ghana to purchase bulk stock of eggs from the farmers and retails to his customers. For lack of adequate working capital, he is not able to pick enough stock to make enough profit to support his family. He wants to use part of the profit to support his kid’s education. He would be grateful for your assistance because with the loan, he wants to purchase bulk supplies of crates of eggs to enable him to scale up his sales. He believes the loan would enable him to save more income to support his business growth also. He belongs to a village bank called ‘Prayer is the key’.

loans.use: To purchase bulk crates of eggs.

loans.name: Amo

texts.en:
Amo is 40 years old. He is married and has five children who are in school. He has been trading in silver and plastic materials like plates, buckets, bowls, cooking utensils etc. for thirteen years now. For the cooking utensils, he sells through hawking that is door-to-door selling. Amo has lots of marketing experience, and it has helped him in his business growth. Demand for his goods is booming on a straight path and he sells during the market days. 
He requests a loan to augment his working capital to buy more stock of silver and plastic materials to sell. He believes the loan will enable him to raise more income to support his family. Amo belongs to a village bank called ‘Maranatha’. This would enable him save more to support his children in school.

loans.use: To buy more cooking utensils and plastics bowls.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is 32 years old and a divorced mother with three kids. All the kids are currently in school. She says selling jewelry is very profitable and therefore has been selling jewelry in the local market for three years to support her family’s needs. With the loan, Lucy wants to buy an increased supply of jewelry to increase her inventory and sales for a good income. She believes this loan would help her save some money to start paying part of the children's school fees and utility bills. She is a member of the group called ‘God is the best’.

loans.use: To buy jewelry in bulk

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis D. is 32 years old. He is married with three children. Two of the children are schooling and the last-born is still breastfeeding. Francis is a dealer in hardware like assorted paints, nails, roofing sheets, hammers, PVC pipes, painting, brushes, head pan etc. at Sefwi, a town where he lives with his family. He buys his supplies from importers in Kumasi, the regional capital of Ashanti region, at wholesale prices and sells to his customers at retail prices. He requests a loan to enable him to procure an increased stock of paints, nails, hammers, head pans, brushes etc to accelerate his business progress. With the loan, he hopes to increase savings to expand his shop. He would be very grateful for your support. He belongs to the village bank called ‘Gye Nyame’ which literary means Except God.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory.

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en:
Ernestina is 32 years old. She is married and a mother with one child. Currently her child is in school at the community of Sefwi where they live. She operates a drinking spot where she sells all kinds of drinks such as soft, canned and bottle drinks etc. Ernestina has raised a wooden kiosk in which she sells the drinks.

She is an achiever and her focus is to save enough to provide her child with a quality education for his future career. But she claims without adequate funds it can’t be possible to realize that dream. She has been running the drinking spot for three years.

She is humbly requesting your help (loan) to make her dream come true so that she would be more resourced to take care of her child and other family needs. With the loan, she wants to purchase increased stock of assorted drinks from the wholesalers to restock her shop. She belongs to the village bank called God time is the best.

loans.use: To buy assorted drinks to upgrade her inventory.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is 42 years old and she is married with two children. All her children are in the junior high. Her husband has been very supportive in taking care of the children.  She works very hard and approaches her business with commitment. For four years, Agnes has been trading in gari sale. Gari is produced from cassava and it is one of the carbohydrate supplements. She obtains her supplies from the farming communities and retail to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy bulk of gari to meet the daily demands of her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to pay her children educational fees. She belongs to the village bank called “Nyame Nsawom” which literally means God has a hand in it.

loans.use: To buy maize and gari in bulk

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
Mrs. Carolina A. is 29 years old.  She has a son in high school, and her husband works in his own business.  Carolina now owns a small grocery store that she runs from her home.  

Previously, she worked as a domestic employee, but as she could not care for her son from that job, she decided to open her own business, selling fruit and vegetables.  The business grew day by day, and finally she was able to turn her stand into a small grocery store.  Her dream is to open a gas and auto service station in order to give her son a better education than the one she received.  She thanks the Fundación Paraguaya for the help she has received and the trust they have placed in her.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and beverages

loans.name: Mario Alberto

texts.es: El Señor Mario Alberto N. A. tiene la edad de 56 años, es un hombre soltero. Tiene 3 hijos a su cargo. La actividad económica a la que se dedica es la venta de comida. Hace más de 7 años que se dedica a este negocio. Inicialmente tenía un negocio de compra y venta de electrodomésticos, pero Mario tuvo problemas de salud como lo es la artritis, y este trabajo consistía en recorrer muchos lugares para ofrecerles a sus clientes los diferentes productos que ofrecía, pero sin embargo este no fue motivo para que Mario renunciara a seguir adelante con otro negocio, por lo que decide establecerse con otro negocio como lo es la venta de comida. El sueño de Mario es de mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda.
texts.en:
Mario Alberto N. A. is 56 and single. He is raising three children. He has been selling food for over seven years. He initially had a business of buying and selling household appliances. But, Mario had health problems, arthritis. With the appliance business he had to travel a lot by going to his customers to show them his different products. Nevertheless, he did not use his health as an excuse. He went ahead and set up another business, which is selling food. Mario’s dream is to improve the condition of his house.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Cerefino

texts.en:
Mr. Cerefino is 47 years old and is married to Mrs. Silvia, with whom he has two older children.

Mr. Cerefino has been a taxi driver for more than twenty years. He currently has two vehicles in his service, which take different customers of Mariano Roque Alonso to neighboring areas. He began his service when he sold a truck that he used in his construction job. He saved a little bit more and then purchased another car.

Mr. Cerefino is asking for this loan in order to repair and maintain his two automobiles.

loans.use: To repair his two taxis

loans.name: Maria Efigenia

texts.es: María Efigenia M. C., tiene la edad de . Es una mujer casada, tiene  a su cargo 2 hijos. La actividad económica de ella es mercadería general, tiene 10 años de tener este negocio. Ella inicia este negocio con la necesidad de obtener una fuente de ingresos para su familia, por lo que su salario no abastecía lo suficiente para el sustento diario de su familia, sus inicios no fueron muy fáciles por lo que tenía que cuidar a sus hijos a la misma ves ofrecer sus productos y sus hijos quedaban completamente solos, ya que muchas veces descuido a sus hijos. Los préstamos que ha recibido de fundación León 2000 han sido siempre destinados para capital de trabajo. Este financiamiento que necesita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de ropa, cosméticos, bolsos y calzados. Los sueños de María son de establecer un negocio en la casa de habitación y mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda.
texts.en:
María Efigenia M. C. is married and is raising her two children. For ten years she has been selling general merchandise. She started this business because she needed to have a source of income for her family. Her salary did not sufficiently cover the daily family expenses. In the beginning, it was not easy because she had to take care of her children at the same time she was selling her products. Her children stayed all alone and many times she neglected them. The loans she has received from the León Foundation 2000 have always been for working capital. This loan that she needs is for working capital to buy clothes, cosmetics, purses, and footwear. María’s dreams are to set up a store in her home and to improve the condition of her home.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Amor Y Seriedad 1 Group

texts.en:
Estela Y. is the group coordinator for this small group of entrepreneurs. She has 8 children; the eldest is 15 and the youngest is 2 years old. Estela understands the importance of providing for all her children, which is why she has a set goal of making her business grow into a successful cafeteria. 

Estela sells food (both uncooked and prepared). She cooks with charcoal because she doesn't have a stove, so part of this loan will be used to buy enough charcoal for her to cook the prepared meals she sells at her stand. The rest of her loan will be invested in purchasing cooking oil. This is one of the most expensive items used for cooking, so it's better purchased in large quantities (a 5 gallon can). Estela will also buy some seasonal fruits and vegetables to cover the demand of those people who make their own food but buy materials from the stand. She hopes that catering to a variety of clients will render her profits that one day will allow her to have her own house.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal and cooking oil to prepare food.

loans.name: Gloria Dolores

texts.es: La Señora Gloria Dolores Berríos Juárez tiene la edad de 61 años, es una mujer casada. Tiene 2 hijos a su cargo. La actividad económica es la venta de comida. Hace mas de 10 años que se dedica a este negocio, Gloria inicio este negocio por la necesidad de proporciónale a sus hijos la alimento diario, ella comenzó estableciendo una pequeña mesa en las afueras de su vivienda, y comenzó ofreciendo al publico gallo pinto, huevos, tajadas entre otras cosas Gloria no tenia el capital suficiente para ofrecer mas comida a sus clientes. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de productos como arroz, aceite, verduras, queso, frijoles y huevos. El deseo de Gloria es mejorar su vivienda y manager activo su negocio.
texts.en:
Gloria Dolores Berríos Juárez, 61, is married and has two children. For over ten years she has been selling food. Gloria started this business because she needed to feed her children. She started by setting up a small table outside of her home. She started selling gallo pinto (red beans and rice), beans, eggs, and tajadas (fried plantain slices) among other things. Gloria did not have enough money to offer her customers more food than that. The loan she is asking for is for working capital to buy products like rice, oil, vegetables, cheese, beans, and eggs. Gloria’s wish is to improve her home and keep her business active.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Amor Y Seriedad 2 Group

texts.en:
These five micro-entrepreneurs live in a small community insiD. La Romana called Batey Magdalena. In order to purchase their inventory, they must travel to the main city of La Romana, which means a long trip by bus or motorcycle. This is why they try to go when they have enough money to buy in bulk, or enough orders. 

Milagros G. is this group's coordinator. She is married to Juan Yan and they have 2 children aged 8 and 2. Milagros sells clothing and accessories. So far, the best system she has found is to take orders of specific items and delivers the products to her customers, who then pay. This way she avoids purchasing merchandise she might not sell. Milagros has been able to create a faithful clientele that effectively employ her as their personal shopper: they ask her for a certain item, and she purchases it to resell to them. 

Milagros would love to have her own house someday; she thinks it would improve her life greatly and she could use the extra money she now uses to pay rent.

loans.use: To buy clothing, shoes and bedding, pre-ordered by her customers.

loans.name: Canal De Bendicion Group

texts.en:
Marielena, the group coordinator, resides in a Batey (small agricultural village) in the La Romana region of the Dominican Republic along with the other members of her credit group. She lives with her husband J. Jimenez and their six children ages 18, 16, 14, 10, 7 and 6. Despite being illiterate she has successfully created a retail business selling various sundry items from a paletera (small retail stand) to support her family. She has been able to expand her business to this point with the help of Esperanza International and this is her third loan, after having successfully repaid the first two.

With her new loan Marielena plans to further expand her offerings by purchasing flour, cooking oil, shoes, saltines, lollipops and charcoal to sell; all items for which she has identified a market. In the long term Marielena plans to expand to the point where she can own and operate a colmado (small retail store). She hopes to do so in order to better support her family. Although she recognizes the difficulty of continuing to expand, she is continuing to look for new products which will be in demand in her area.

loans.use: To buy flour, cooking oil, shoes, saltines, charcoal and lollipops

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.es:
CANDELARIA B. M.

La Sra. Candelaria B. tiene 48 años y 2 menores hijos que dependen de ella, tiene un negocio de venta de tubérculos y verduras en el mercado de santa Clara.

Durante su vida la socia tuvo muchos problemas tales como accidentes, una de ellas de cuidado al punto de hospitalizarla juntamente con su conyugue recuperándose totalmente;  pensó que debía tener un negocio que le diera tiempo para estar cerca de sus hijos que son lo mas importante para ella,

fue entonces que  juntamente con sus vecinas de la zona empezaron a vender productos de todo tipo en forma ambulatoria en la  avenida principal por donde ella vivía, luego se organizaron para formalizar sus negocios y comprar un puesto; con tremendo sacrificio pero mucha constancia logro ahorrar y pudo adquirir su puesto propio  y comenzó su venta mas organizada.

La venta le ha traído muchas satisfacciones ya que pudo construir su casa y mejorar la infraestructura de su negocio, ella esta muy contenta con su trabajo realizado por eso desea seguir trabajando ahora para los estudios universitarios de sus hijos.

El crédito otorgado lo invertirá en comprar mas mercadería y seguir con su prospero negocio. Es por ella que aconseja a sus compañeras que a pesar de las circunstancias de la vida debemos de perseverar en el trabajo y seguir adelante.
texts.en:
CANDELARIA B. M. La Sra. Candelaria B. tiene 48 años y 2 menores hijos que dependen de ella, tiene un negocio de venta de tubérculos y verduras en el mercado de santa Clara. Durante su vida la socia tuvo muchos problemas tales como accidentes, una de ellas de cuidado al punto de hospitalizarla juntamente con su conyugue recuperándose totalmente; pensó que debía tener un negocio que le diera tiempo para estar cerca de sus hijos que son lo mas importante para ella, fue entonces que juntamente con sus vecinas de la zona empezaron a vender productos de todo tipo en forma ambulatoria en la avenida principal por donde ella vivía, luego se organizaron para formalizar sus negocios y comprar un puesto; con tremendo sacrificio pero mucha constancia logro ahorrar y pudo adquirir su puesto propio y comenzó su venta mas organizada. La venta le ha traído muchas satisfacciones ya que pudo construir su casa y mejorar la infraestructura de su negocio, ella esta muy contenta con su trabajo realizado por eso desea seguir trabajando ahora para los estudios universitarios de sus hijos. El crédito otorgado lo invertirá en comprar mas mercadería y seguir con su prospero negocio. Es por ella que aconseja a sus compañeras que a pesar de las circunstancias de la vida debemos de perseverar en el trabajo y seguir adelante.

Translated from Spanish by N Aviva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: COMPRAR MERCADERIA

loans.name: Canal De Bendicion 6 Group

texts.en:
These five micro-entrepreneurs live in Batey 18. This is a small settlement around one of the many sugar cane fields in La Romana. The sugar cane fields are owned by a private company, who also owns the houses in the batey and has some control over the commercial activities allowed inside the batey. This forces many of the batey inhabitants to leave their home and their children for extended periods of time to sell their goods. 

Mariluz M., the group coordinator, has 3 children (ages 11, 9 and 4). She sells two different things: candy and snacks, which she sells from a palatera (a small market stand) and chorizo (a type of sausage). This loan, which is Mariluz's very first loan with Esperanza, will allow her to purchase merchandise for both of her sales. 

However, Mariluz does not intend to remain a seller. She intends to learn beauty culture and open a beauty salon in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase candy and chorizo to sell.

loans.name: Guerreros Para Cristo 1 Group

texts.en:
Irene L. and the other members of this group live on Batey 18. This is a small settlement inhabited mainly by the families of the sugar cane field workers. The houses in this community belong to the sugar cane company. Because the wages are extremely low, and during the off-season there is no other income for the batey, a lot of people, especially women, become self-employed.
 
Irene is illiterate. This makes her access to formal employment almost null. She is married to Lisua Rene. They have 4 children, out of whom 2 live with them still. Irene has a small candy stand. She explains it's difficult to do business in her community because a lot of people sell the same things. She sometimes goes to sell on the streets of nearby communities to sell her merchandise. The other challenge she faces is the size of her community. Batey 18 has only 3 streets. 

Irene would like to continue investing in her business and saving towards a future expansion (hopefully outside of her batey). She hopes her hard work allows her to buy a house for her retirement.

loans.use: To purchase candy and snacks to sell.

loans.name: Amor Y Seriedad 3 Group

texts.en:
Elsi L., the group coordinator of Amor y Seriedad, resides in a batey (a small agricultural village) in the La Romana Region of the Dominican Republic. She lives at home with her husband, Yenes Polis, and their four children, aged 15, 10, 5, and 3. Despite receiving limited formal education, she has thus far been able to use her business savvy and hard work to own and operate her own colmado (small retail store). Elsi has been assisted by a loan from Esperanza which she successfully repaid.

With her new loan Elsi aims to purchase more inventory for her colmado including charcoal, shoes and meat. Additionally, she has recognized that, given the diverse fashion sense of her clientele and her limited space and resources, that she can most efficiently sell clothing by offering it to order, a setup in which she will collect several orders and then purchase the desired items from a larger city. She intends to use a portion of her new loan to establish this new element of her business.

Elsi's dream for the the future of her business is to continue growing and, for her family, she envisions using her new earnings to purchase a house for her family to live in. This will be a considerable advantage over paying the rent that she currently pays.

loans.use: To buy new inventory for her store including shoes, meat, charcoal and pre-ordered clothing

loans.name: Flor De Canela De Jovenes Group

texts.es:
La Asociación Comunal  “Flor de Canela de Jóvenes” tiene cuatro integrantes, su presidente es Oscar M., quién tiene el negocio de costura y utilizará el préstamo para comprar materia prima, como es la tela. Oscar actualmente trabaja solo pero su objetivo es montar una microempresa, contar con activos fijos y tener empleados. Los demás integrantes de la Asociación también tienen negocios como el tejido de guantes, costura y venta de ropa, ellos también utilizaran el préstamo  para la compra de materia prima.
Los cuatro se mostraron muy motivados a trabajar juntos y apoyarse mutuamente.
texts.en:
The community organization “Flor de Canela de Jóvenes” has four members. Its president is Oscar M., who has a sewing business and will use this loan to purchase raw materials like cloth. Oscar currently works alone but his goal is to start a small business with fixed assets and to have employees.

The other members of the association also have their own businesses, like knitting gloves, sewing, and clothing sales. They will also use the loan to purchase raw materials.

The four members are very motivated to work together and support each other.

Translated from Spanish by Mary McKee, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy fertilizers

loans.name: Alicia

texts.es: Doña Alicia V. de 46 años de edad, originario del municipio de Tecpan Guatemala, Tiene 9 hijos, desde muy corta edad ella se caracteriza como líder, e innovadora, se dedica a elaborar prendas de vestir del área, es una señora muy emprendedora, estuvo en proyecto, de invernadero con muchas socias, como enseñanza, logra tener mucha experiencia, inicia con su propio invernadero, haciendo prestamos pequeños, pero con sus gastos con sus hijos no le alcanza para invertir, para poder, obtener mas ganancia, ahora necesita comprar fertilizantes, fungicida, y otros, para mantener su invernadero de tomate, su sueño para sus hijos es lograr una cartera ya que ahora sus dos hijos mayores le ayudan y se graduaron de mecánica automotriz, su sueños es tener otro invernadero mas grande y apoyar siempre a sus hijos con mejor alimentación, construir unas habitaciones ya que solo tienen 3 para tantas personas.
texts.en:
Alicia V. is 46 and a native of the Tecpan municipality in Guatemala. She has nine children. Since a very young age she has been characterized as a leader and an innovator. She makes clothing that is typical in her area. She is a very enterprising woman. She was in a greenhouse project with many other members. It was a learning project, and she gained much experience. She set up her own greenhouse by making small loans. But, with the children’s expenses she does not have enough working capital. To earn more she needs to buy fertilizer, fungicide, and other things to keep her greenhouse of tomatoes. Her dream for her children is that they have careers. Her two older children help her now. They graduated as automobile mechanics. Her dreams are to have another, bigger greenhouse, to always support her children with the best food, and to build some bedrooms since they now only have three for so many people.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizers

loans.name: Apostol Santiago Group

texts.es:
Las socias del Banco Comunal Apóstol Santiago son de la comunidad de Pucacruz, Distrito de Rosario, Provincia de Acobamba, las actividades principales de la comunidad son la siembra de cereales y crianza de animales.
Como es el caso de Josefa que es casada, tiene 6 hijos, Josefa se dedica a la compra y venta de cereales, papa, además Josefa se dedica al procesamiento de los cereales y papa, como el chuño (elaborado de papa), maíz y trigo pelado, productos que vende en la feria de su región, el préstamo que obtendrá será invertido en la compra de cereales variados, los sueños de Josefa son que sus hijos sean profesionales.
Por otro lado Maria es viuda, tiene 8 hijos, Maria compra animales menores en las diferentes ferias de la región y lo vende en Acobamba, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de sus hijos mayores, su préstamo será invertido en la compra de animales menores y tambien para implementar una tienda de abarrotes. Los sueños de Maria son que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
The members of the Apóstol Santiago Community Bank are from the Pucacruz community, Rosario district, Acobamba province. The community’s main activities are planting grains and raising animals. For examples, Josefa is married and has six children. She buys and sells grains and potatoes. Josefa also processes the grains and potatoes into chuño (potato flour) and hulled corn and wheat. She sells these products at the fair in her region. The loan is to buy various grains. Josefa’s dream is that her children become professionals. On the other hand, Maria is a widow with eight children. She buys small animals in the different regional fairs. She sells them in Acobamba. She does this with the help of her older children. Her loan is to buy small animals and also to set up a small grocery store. Maria’s dreams are that her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy grains, small animals, rice, sugar, potatoes

loans.name: Los Lirios Group

texts.es:
Las socias del Banco Comunal Los lirios son de la comunidad de Tinquerccassa, Distrito de Paucara, Provincia de Acobamba, las actividades principales de la comunidad son la siembra de cereales y la crianza de animales.
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios, un ejemplo es Martina que es casada, tiene 5 hijos, Martina viaja a las ferias de su región en donde vende frutas variadas, sus ventas lo realiza con la ayuda de su esposo, su préstamo será invertido en la compra de frutas. Los sueños de Martina son que sus hijos sean profesionales, comprar un carro para transportar sus productos y vender al por mayor.
Por otro lado Feliciana es casada, tiene 5 hijos, Feliciana viaja a los diferentes pueblos de la zona en donde compra animales y luego los comercializa en la feria de su región, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su esposo, su préstamo será invertido en la compra de animales. El sueño de Feliciana es ampliar su negocio.
texts.en:
The members of the Community Bank Los Lirios are from the community of Tinquerccassa, District of Paucara, Acobamba Province. The main activities in the community are farming cereals and raising animals. The members work in different businesses. One example is Martina, who is married and has 5 children. Martina travels to various markets in her region where different fruits are sold. Her sales are completed with the help of her husband. Her loan will be invested in the purchase of fruit. Martina's dreams are that her children will be professionals, to purchase a car to transport her products, and to sell wholesale. Another example is Feliciana, who is married and also has 5 children. Feliciana travels to different towns in the region where she purchases animals, which she later sells in the regional markets, an activity she undertakes with the help of her husband. Her loan will be invested in the purchase of animals. Feliciana's dream is to increase her business.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fruit, small animals, cereals, cheeses, and general groceries.

loans.name: Wiñaipaq Quñukusun Group

texts.es:
Las socias del Banco Comunal Wiñaypaq Quñukusun (Juntémonos para crecer) son D. la comunidad D. Calzada, Distrito D. Rosario, Provincia D. Acobamba, las principales actividades D. la comunidad son la agricultura y la ganadería.
Las socias tiene diferentes negocios como es el caso D. Dionisia que es casada, tiene 3 hijos, Dionisia se dedica a la compra y venta D. animales menores, Dionisia se dedica al engorD. D. animales, actividad que realiza con la ayuda D. su esposo e hijos, su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. animales. Los sueños D. Dionisia es construir su casa.
Alicia es madres soltera, tiene 1 hijo, Alicia se dedica a la compra D. animales en las diferentes ferias D. la región, su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. animales menores. Los sueños D. Alicia son comprar una chacra para sembrar alfalfa.
texts.en:
The members of the Community Bank Comunal Wiñaypaq Quñukusun (We join to grow) are from the community of Calzada, district of Rosario, Acobamba Province. The main activities in the community are agriculture and raising livestock.

The members have different businesses, as in the case of Dionisia, who is married and has 3 children. Dionisia is dedicated to the purchase and sale of small animals. She fattens the animals, an activity she undertakes with the help of her husband. Her loan will be invested in the purhcase of animals. Dionisia's dream is to build a house.

Alicia is a single mother of one child. She dedicates herself to the sale of animals in the different markets in her region, and her loan will be invested in the purhcase of small animals. Alicia's dream is to purchase a small farm to grow alfalfa.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of small animals, cereals, potatoes and cheese.

loans.name: San Salvador Group

texts.es:
Las socias del Banco Comunal San Salvador son D. la comunidad D. Circamarca, Distrito D. Huancaraylla, Provincia D. Víctor Fajardo, las actividades principales D. la comunidad son la siembra D. cereales y la crianza D. animales.
Claudia es casada, tiene 6 hijos, Claudia desD. muy joven aprendió a comprar y vender animales en las diferentes ferias D. la región, la carne lo venD. en la feria D. la ciudad D. Cangallo, actividad que realiza con la ayuda D. su esposo, su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. animales menores. Los sueños D. Claudia son que sus hijos menores culminen con sus estudios.
Mientras que Maria es casada y tiene 3 hijos, Maria tiene una Bodega en su casa en donD. abarrotes en general, sus productos los adquiere en la ciudad D. Huamanga, su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. arroz, azúcar y también surtirá su negocio con lencería. Los sueños D. Maria son educar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales.
texts.en:
The members of Community Bank San Salvador are from the community of Circamarca, district of Huancaraylla, Víctor Fajardo Province. The main activities in the community are farming grains and raising animals.

Claudia is married and has 6 children. From a very young age, Claudia learned to buy and sell animals in the different markets in the region, and sell the meat at the market in the city of Cangallo. She undertakes this activity with the help of her husband, and her loan will be invested in the purchase of small animals. Claudia's dream is that her youngest children complete their studies.

Meanwhile, Maria is married and has 3 children. Maria has a small shop in her home offering general groceries. She acquires her inventory in the city of Huamanga, and her loan will be invested in the purchase of rice and sugar, and she will also stock her shop with linens. Maria's dream is to educate her children so that they become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of small animals, rice, sugar, oil, fruit and cheeses.

loans.name: Rosa Wilma

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Wilma, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres para el Futuro II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 36 años y es madre de 03 hijos, los 03 que aun dependen de ella.

Lleva 03 años dedicándose a la venta de abarrotes. Rosita se inicio, con un capital de 100.00, vendiendo en una mesita en las fueras de su casa.
Nos cuenta que tuvo que pasar por altas y bajas, para llegar a ser una pequeña empresaria y administrar su propio negocio y generar sus propios ingresos, sin dar cuentas a nadie. 
Con su esfuerzo y vigor, llego a implementar ahora su bodega, es muy conocida por sus clientes en el barrio donde vive y sus ventas diarias son buenas . En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio ubicada en su misma casa.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00 , lo invertirá comprando más productos para surtir su negocio como arroz y azúcar en sacos, insumos para el aseo personal, gaseosas en paquetes y productos variados para mantener contenta a su clientela. 

Ella es una mujer con muchas ganas de salir adelante para el bienestar de su familia y de ella misma. 

Rosa Wilma, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Rosa Wilma is a member of the Mujeres Para el Futuro II ("Women for the Future II") Village Bank in Tarapoto District of San Martin Department. She is 36 years old and is the single mother of three children, all of whom are still dependents. Rosa Wilma, or "Rosita," has been selling basic groceries for the past three years. Rosita started with a loan of 100 soles and sold goods from a table outside her home. She says that she went through her ups and downs on her way to becoming a small business owner who administers her own business and generates her own income, without having to report to anyone else. With her effort and vigor, Rosita was able to open a small neighborhood store in her home, which is now very well-known by clients in her neighborhood. Her daily sales are strong. With this loan of 1000 soles, Rosita will buy more products in order to offer a wider variety of merchandise in her store. She plans to buy sacks of rice and sugar, personal hygeine products, packs of soda, and a variety of other products to keep her clients happy. She is a woman who strongly wants to get ahead in life, for the well-being of her family and herself. Rosa Wilma would like to express her gratitude to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as a businessperson and as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy basic grocery items (rice, sugar, soda, etc)

loans.name: Dinora Elena

texts.es:
La señora Dinora Elena, pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Paz II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia San Martin, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 22 y 02 hijos que aun dependen de ella.

Motivada por su espíritu joven y su energía emprendedora, iniciaron ella y su pareja su propio negocio  de servicio de vulcanizado de llantas , con un capital de S/. 300.00, su taller se encuentra ubicado en un local muy bien acondicionado, cuenta con clientes fijos y es ella quien  los atiende con su carisma y buen trato.
En la actualidad continúa con el mismo negocio, esta satisfecha con lo que hace y con los ingresos que genera a diario, así se siente muy responsable y puntual con sus cuotas a pagar en el Banco Comunal.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500.00, comprará  una maquina compresora, una prensa y plancha y un esmeril de banco. Parte del dinero también lo invertirá comprando repuestos y lubricantes, productos que también tiene agregado para satisfacer a sus clientes.

 Se siente muy contenta, ya que pese a las dificultades supo salir adelante junto a su pareja y familia, por lo que reconoce y agradece el apoyo que el Movimiento Manuela Ramos le viene brindando a ella y otras mujeres, que quieren emprender su negocio y generar sus propios ingresos, así también salir adelante solas, sin depender de nadie.
texts.en:
Dinora Elena belongs to the "La Paz II" communal bank in the district of Tarapoto, Mariscal Cáceres Province in the state of San Martín. She is single, 22 years old and has 2 dependent children. Motivated by her young spirit and entrepeneurial energy, her husband and her started their own business vulcanizing tires with 300 Nuevos Soles in capital. The workshop is located in a well airconditioned location and they have regular clients that they take care of with charisma and very good treatment. Currently, she continues with the same business; she is satisfied with what she does and with the income that she earns daily. She is very responsible and punctual with the payments to the communal bank. With this loan of 1,500 Nuevos Soles she will buy a compressor machine, a press, an iron and a bench grinder. Part of the money will be invested in the purchase of spart parts and lubricants, products that are used to satisfy her clients. She is very happy since despite the difficulties she faced, she, along with her family, were able to get ahead which is why she acknowledges and is grateful for the support that the Manuela Ramos organization provides to her and other women that want to start their own business and earn their own income to be able get ahead on their own without depending on anyone.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of tools for business

loans.name: Zuly Del Rosario

texts.es:
La señora Zuly del Rosario A. R. tiene 36 años, vive en el distrito de El Porvenir, en la provincia de Trujillo en el Departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió Secundaria Completa, tiene 3 hijos que dependen económicamente de ella.
Zuly cuando inició tenía como negocio la venta de insumos para la preparación de alimentos en el mercado luego por falta de tiempo y para brindarles mayor atención a sus hijos empezó con el negocio de la venta de ropa (lencería) , con el cual permanece actualmente. Su producto los distribuye a domicilio y trabaja solo con pedidos.
Su mercadería lo obtiene en Trujillo (Centros Comerciales).
Con el crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal Viva con Esperanza II, lo invirtió en la compra de insumos para su bodega.
Con este crédito de 300 soles, lo invertirá en la compra de mercadería (lencería fina).
Zuly tiene como sueño tener una tienda surtida de abarrotes y también de venta de ropa en general.
texts.en:
Mrs. Zuly del Rosario A. R. is 36 years old and has three dependent children. She lives in the El Provenir District of Trujillo Province in La Libertad, Peru, and has a high school education. When she first became a Manuela Ramos client, Zuly sold basic cooking ingredients in the local market. Then, because of a lack of time and in order to spend more time with her children, she started selling lingerie, which she continues to do today. She delivers her products to her clients' homes, and works only with orders. She buys her merchandise in the Commercial Centers of the city of Trujillo. Zuly is a member of the Viva Con Esperanza II ("Live With Hope II") Village Bank. She used her first loan of 300 soles to buy ingredients for her small grocery store. She will use this loan to buy fine lingerie. Zuly's dream is to have a grocery store with a wide variety of merchandise where she can also sell clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fine lingerie

loans.name: Carolina

texts.es:
La señora Carolina, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Estrellitas de Jorge Chávez II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 57 años, 03 hijos ya independientes y con familia.

El haber pasado por momentos muy duros durante su vida, le motivo a emprender su propio negocio de venta de lubricantes, nos cuenta que se inicio desde abajo y lleva 05 años dedicándose a este negocio,  ubicada en su misma casa. Luego con su primer prestamo de Manuela Ramos y con su apoyo siguió invirtiendo mas, hasta la fecha su negocio se encuentra surtido de diferentes productos que ofrece a sus clientes, en el barrio ya es muy conocida  tiene muy buenas ventas al día y al mes.

Sus principales clientes son chóferes de autos, volvos y motocarristas y motociclistas que a diario acuden a su tienda a comprar porque en ella  encuentran todo los productos que necesitan para sus unidades motorizadas y es quien personalmente les atiende  con su carisma que la caracteriza.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, lo invertirá comprando lubricantes como: 05 baldes de Aceites Castrol y Shell, otros productos como pernos de rueda, centrales, abrazaderas, cámaras y ponchos.

Carolina, como mujer se siente muy contenta con lo logrado a lo largo de su vida, y con mayor esfuerzo desea ver a sus hijos profesionales. Agradece a Manuela Ramos por haberla ayudado  a superararce y realizarse como empresaria.
texts.en:
Mrs. Carolina is a member of the Community Bank "Las Estrellitas Jorge Chavez II", Tarapoto district - San Martin Province, San Martín state. She is a 57 year old woman and has 3 children who are independent and have their own family.

She went through very hard times during her life and got motivated to start her own business selling engine oils. She has been in the business for 5 years and is it is located at her home. She invested Manuela Ramos' first loan in the business and currently offers a variety of products to her customers. She is well known in the neighborhood and has very good sales per day and per month. Her main customers are car drivers, motorcyclists and moto-taxi drivers that daily come to her store because of the variety of products she offers. She is who personally take care of the customers with her charisma.

She is asking for a loan of $350 that will use to buy engine oils and other products such as wheel bolts, centers, cameras and ponchos. As a woman feels very happy with what she has accomplished throughout her life, and hopes to see her children as professionals. She thanks Manuela Ramos for helping her to be an entrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Domitila

texts.es:
La señora Domitila, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Señor de Los Milagros”  que esta ubicado en la Comunidad de Imicati, distrito de Yunguyo, Provincia de Chucuito, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 35 años de edad, estado civil casada y tiene 6 hijos, tiene estudios de educación primaria completa, y vive en el  Centro Poblado de Imicati.

Trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 1 año,  con un préstamo inicial de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, el cual lo utilizo para su negocio de compra y venta de cereales. 

En este momento ella requiere un préstamo de S/. 1000.00 Nuevos soles, para poder invertir en su actual negocio la compra y venta de cereales,  que luego los lleva a la ciudad de Arequipa.

Su mayor sueño es poder darles educación a sus hijos y tener un criadero de ganado para engorde.

A ella le gustan los ahorros, y los encuentros de Bancos Comunales.
texts.en:
Mrs Domitila belongs to the Community Bank “Señor de Los Milagros” which is located in the Imicati Community, Yunguyo district, Chucuito Province, Department of Puno. She is 35 years old, is married and has 6 children. She completed her primary education and lives in the town of Imicati.

She has been working with the Manuela Ramos movement for a year, with an initial loan of 300 Peruvian soles, which she used for her business buying and selling cereals.

Now she requires a loan of 1000 soles to invest in her current business buying and selling cereals, which she takes to the town of Arequipa.

Her great dream is to be able to give her children an education and to have a herd of cattle to fatten up.

She likes the savings and the Community Bank meetings.

Translated from Spanish by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Niria Nereyda

texts.es:
La señora Niria Nereyda Briceño M. tiene 42 años, vive en el Distrito de La Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió Secundaria Completa,   tiene 3  hijos que depende económicamente de ella.
Niria se dedica a la venta de antenas, cortadores de vidrios, su negocio lo desarrolla en las esquinas de la ciudad de Trujillo.
Con su primer crédito de 200 soles que recibió de su Banco Comunal Nueva Esperanza  II, lo invirtió  en la compra de productos como cortadores de vidrios.
Este crédito de 1700 soles, lo invertirá en la compra de  antenas, enciclopedias ilustradas y con CDs para implementar su negocio.
Niria tiene como sueño implementar su ferretería para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Niria Nereyda Briceño M. is 42. She lives in the Esperanza district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Perú. She completed high school. She has three dependent children. Niria sells antennas and glass cutters. She sells on the corners in the city of Trujillo. With her first loan for 200 PEN, which she received from her Community Bank Nueva Esperanza II, she bought products like glass cutters. With this loan for 1,700 PEN, she will buy antennas and illustrated encyclopedias with CDs to set up her business. Niria’s dream is to set up her hardware store in order to grow as an entrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy antennas and illustrated encyclopedias with CDs to set up her business

loans.name: Llaque Reyna

texts.es:
La señora LLaque Reyna, pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Paz II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 28 años y 02 hijos, que aun dependen de ella.

El espíritu luchador que siempre le ha caracterizado y las ganas de salir adelante con sus propios medios le ha valido para iniciar su propio negocio de venta de comidas  en el patio de su casa donde poco a poco fue haciéndose muy conocida entre sus clientes y hoy nos cuenta que le va muy bien en este tipo de actividad. 
En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio donde vende diariamente  por las noches  y durante el día combina esta actividad con el servicio de transporte urbano utilizando su motocarro. 

Con el préstamo de S/ 2,000.00, desea invertirlo comprando insumos como: arroz en sacos, huevos, gallinas criollas para sus juanes y pollos desviscerados para sus anticuchos, asimismo utensilios de cocina para brindar un servicio de calidad.  

Reynita,  se siente tranquila y contenta con lo que hace  y  agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Llaque Reyna belongs to the La Paz II Community Bank in the Tarapoto district, San Martín province, San Martín department. She is 28, married, and has two dependent children. The fighting spirit that has always characterized her and the desire to get ahead by her own means have served her well to set up her own business. She sells meals on the patio of her house. Little by little she has become very well known among her customers. The business is currently going very well for her. She continues with the same business. She sells every evening. During the day she combines this activity with an urban transportation service using her motorcycle cart. With this loan for 2,000 PEN she wants to buy supplies like sacks of rice, eggs, and chickens to make her ‘juanes’, a dish traditionally eaten in the Peruvian rainforest. It’s made from chicken, rice, olives, and eggs and wrapped in a special leaf. She will also buy gutted chicken for her “anticuchos” (kebobs). For herself, she will buy kitchen utensils to offer quality service. Reynita feels peaceful and happy with what she does. She is grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for contributing to the fulfillment of her dreams and goals.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for meal preparation (rice, eggs, chickens)

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es:
La señora Gregoria, pertenece al Banco Comunal “El Tiempo es Oro”, Distrito D. Juanjui, Departamento D. Mariscal Cáceres. Es Casada, tiene 63 años y es madre D. 05 hijos todos ellos ya independientes y  con familia.

Lleva varios años dedicándose al rubro D. alquiler D. cuartos, nos cuenta que se inicio con S/. 800.00 en la construcción D. la primera habitación y el esfuerzo y las ganas D. salir adelante, le hizo desarrollarse poco a poco en este negocio.
Cuenta que le va muy bien, en la actualidad tiene 05 habitaciones en alquiler ubicada en su misma casa, habitaciones muy bien cómodas y bien arregladas.

Con el préstamo D. S/. 2,000.00, lo invertirá comprando ladrillos, cementos, triplay, así mismo mandará a confeccionar puertas y ventanas D. madera,  para la construcción D. mas dormitorios, al frente D. su casa.

Ella es quien toma las decisiones en las ganancias D. su negocio, en lo personal, se siente más, segura y capaz.

Gregoria; manifiesta su Agradecimiento al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por haberle ayudado a mejorar y hacer posible sus sueños y poder así asegurar su vejez generando sus propios ingresos.
texts.en:
Gregoria belongs to the El Tiempo es Oro Community Bank in the Juanjui district, Mariscal Cáceres department. She is 63, married, and the mother of five independent children who have their own families. She has been renting out rooms for several years. She started with 800 PEN, which she used to build the first room. Her effort and desire to get ahead helped her to little by little develop in this business. It is going very well for her. She currently has five rooms that she rents out; the rooms are located in her own house. They are very comfortable and well put together. With this loan for 2,000 PEN she will buy bricks, cement, and three layered plywood. She herself will be in charge of making the doors and windows from wood in order to build more bedrooms in the front of her house. She is the one who makes the decisions about the earnings from her business. Personally, she feels more self-confident and capable. Gregoria is grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for having helped her improve and make her dreams possible. This way she can be assured of generating her own income in her old age.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Rent rooms

loans.name: Timotea Irene

texts.es:
La señora Timotea Irene C. Rubiños tiene 45 años, vive en el Distrito de La Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.  Es socia del Banco comunal Nueva Esperanza  II.
Ella estudió Secundaria Incompleta,  no tiene  hijos que depende económicamente de ella.
Timotea se dedica a la venta de Productos de Belleza, su negocio lo desarrolla en su casa.
Con este primer crédito de 300 soles, lo invertirá en la compra de productos de Belleza como colonias, cremas, champús, lápices labiales para implementar su negocio.
Timotea tiene como sueño implementar su restaurante para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Mrs. Timotea Irene C. Rubiños is 45 years old and lives in the La Esperanza district of Trujillo in La Libertad, Peru. She is a member of the communal bank “Nueva Esperanza II.” Timotea studied some high school. She has no dependent children. Timotea sells beauty products from her home. With this first loan of 300 soles, she will buy beauty products like: colognes, creams, shampoos, and lipsticks to get her business going. She dreams of having her own restaurant so she can grow as a small business owner.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: La compra de productos de Belleza como colonias, cremas, champús, lápices labiales para implementar su negocio.

loans.name: Carmen Ruth

texts.es:
La señora Carmen Ruth Martínez Z. tiene 62 años, vive en el Distrito de La Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió Superior  Secretariado Ejecutivo,  no tiene  hijos que depende económicamente de ella.
Carmen se dedica a la Elaboración de Carteras y Almohadones bordadas en cintas y tejidos, su negocio lo desarrolla en su casa.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco comunal Nueva Esperanza  II, lo invirtió en la compra de materiales como cintas, hilos, broches, lentejuelas y telas.
El crédito de 500 soles, lo invertirá en la compra de  materiales como cintas, hilos, broches, lentejuelas y telas para implementar su negocio.
Carmen tiene como sueño aprehender más manualidades como bisutería para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Mrs. Carmen Ruth Martínez Z. is 62 years old and lives in the La Espranza district of Trujillo in La Libertad, Peru. Carmen studied to be an executive secretary. She has no dependent children. Carmen makes wallets and embroidered pillows for a living and works from home. She bought materials like: belts, thread, brooches, sequins and fabric with the first loan of 300 soles she received through her communal bank “Nueva Esperanza.” This loan of 500 soles will be invested in the purchase of similar materials needed for her business. Carmen has a dream of learning how to make more crafts like making costume jewelry so she can grow as a small business owner.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de cintas, hilos, broches, lentejuelas y telas para implementar su negocio.

loans.name: Jesus Nelida

texts.es:
La señora Jesús Nélida G. D. A. tiene 55 años, vive en el distrito D. El Porvenir, en la provincia D. Trujillo en el Departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió Primaria Completa, tiene 1 nieta que depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Nélida tiene como negocio la venta D. menú (la venta lo realiza todos los días). 
Cuando inicio con Manuela Ramos vendía comida en lo que anteriormente se le denominaba   La Parada  “Mercado Santa Rosa” (distrito El Porvenir), Su negocio estaba ubicado al costado D. su domicilio, en un club D. madres. Luego con el pasar del tiempo se trasladó su negocio a su domicilio.
Los insumos para la preparación D. alimentos los obtiene en los mercados D. abastos D. su distrito.
Con el crédito D. 300 soles que recibió D. su Banco Comunal Viva con Esperanza, lo invirtió en la compra D. insumos como arroz, azúcar y sal (esto comprado al por mayor).
Con el crédito D. 800 soles continuara invirtiéndolo en la compra D. insumos como azúcar y sal.
Jesús tiene como sueño construir su casa y así poder alquilar dormitorios porque considera que con el pasar D. los años y en su edad avanzada ya no podrá seguir trabajando igual.
texts.en:
Mrs. Jesús Nélida G. D. A. is 55 years old and lives in the El Porvenir district of Trujillo in La Libertad, Peru. She completed graD. school and has a grandchild she takes care of. Nélida sells menú (prepared plates of food) for a living. She sells menú seven days a week. When she started with Manuela Ramos, she sold food in what used to be called La Parada Mercado Santa Rosa. Her business was located next to her home in a club for mothers. She eventually moved her business into her home. She buys the supplies she needs for her business in the wholesale markets in her area. She bought supplies like rice and salt with the first loan of 300 soles received from her communal bank “Viva con Esperanza.” She will again buy supplies like sugar and salt with this new loan of 800 soles. Jesús dreams of building a house to be able to rent out rooms because she feels that as she gets older she won’t be able to keep doing the same work.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: La compra de insumos como azúcar y sal.

loans.name: Estela

texts.en: Mrs. Estela works selling grilled meat at night and selling fruits and vegetables by day. Thanks to the Fundación she was able to save enough capital to start a business selling used clothing that comes from Brazil. Her dream is to be able to have a general store in her house where she sells clothing. She would also like to open a hair salon for her daughter who really enjoys that profession.

loans.use: To purchase winter clothing for sale

loans.name: Gioconda

texts.es:
En la ciudad de León, la señora Gioconda M. se dedica a su actividad de servicio de salón de belleza el cual ha logrado levantar en su propia casa de habitación y a pesar que no presta cien por ciento con las condiciones para trabajar, ella ha logrado mejorar su condición de vida por medio del negocio.

Actualmente ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito y es por esta razón que espera muy confiadamente en que su crédito sea otorgado para proceder a la compra de los materiales de trabajo en el salón tales como peines, cremas, espejos, gelatina, entre otros, y de esta manera mejorar la condición del negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Giaconda M. lives in the city of Leon, where she has a beauty salon business at her house. Although she does not have 100% of what she needs in order to work, she has managed to improve her living conditions through the business. She is asking for a loan to Ceprodel, and is very confident that she will get it, so she can start to buy working materials for her beauty salon such us combs, creams, mirrors, gels, among others, to improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
La señora Martha, pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Marginal II”, vive en la Jr. Jiménez Pimentel Nº 1034, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 38 años, 02 hijos 01 que aun depende de ella y le ayuda en sus ventas.

Martha, lleva ya varios años dedicándose al negocio de venta al por mayor y menor, nos cuenta que ya lleva varios años dedicándose a este tipo de negocio.

En la Actualidad continua con el mismo negocio y ahora ya tiene una clientela fija que mes a mes realizan sus pedidos, ya que ella trabaja así y como también va ofreciendo a sus amigos, familiares y vecinos, le va muy bien y mensualmente genera sus propios ingresos, y con el carisma que tiene sus ventas le salen a pedir de boca.

Con el préstamo de S/ 1,200.00, desea invertirlo comprando 100 paquetes de gaseosas, en todos los sabores y colores y diferentes tamaños. También lo complementara con paquetes de agua mineral con y sin gas.

Martha, se siente muy contenta por lo logrado, feliz por que en su negocio le va muy bien. Esta muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudarla en iniciar su negocio y también a muchas mujeres que  quieren crecer empresarialmente.
texts.en:
Mrs. Martha is a member of the Community Bank "La Marginal II", lives in Tarapoto district - San Martin Province, San Martín State. She is 38 years old and has 2 children, one of whom still depends on her and helps in the business. Martha has been engaged in the wholesale/ retail business for several years. She is still in the same business and has an established customer base that make orders every month. Since she also offer her products to her friends, relatives and neighbors, is doing very well and has her own monthly income. Because of her charisma the sales are doing very well. She is asking for a loan of $425 that will invest to buy 100 packs of soda, in all different flavors, colors and sizes; as well as packs of mineral water with and without gas. Martha feels very happy about what she has achieved and that her business is doing very well. She thanks Manuela Ramos movement for their help to start her business and also the help that they offer to many entrepreneur women.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy packs of soft drinks

loans.name: Manuela

texts.es:
La señora Manuela, pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Paz II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia San Martin, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 38 años y es madre de 02 hijas, todas ellas ya independientes, pero que la apoyan en el negocio.

Tiene años dedicándose a este tipo de actividad, brindando servicio de llamadas telefónicas local, nacional e internacional , su negocio se encuentra ubicada en un local muy bien acondicionado, para atender a sus clientes. Se inicio con el primer prestamo de Manuela Ramos, comprando un celular y un teléfono, todo esto para empezar. Así, siguió superándose y hoy en la actualidad, continua con el mismo negocio, donde brinda el servicio, a los moradores de la comunidad. 

 Con este préstamo de S/.1,500.00,  comprara mas celulares y teléfonos fijos, para así brindar un mejor servicio y atender mucho mejor al cliente, parte del dinero también lo invertirá comprando tarjetas virtuales y físicas.

Hoy, es una mujer independiente, y ella es la que administra y toma las decisiones en su negocio.
Manuela dice: Que el pertenecer a un grupo de mujeres le ha ayudado a conocer mejor sus derechos y juntas  hacer que estas sean respetadas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Manuela is a member of the Community Bank "La Paz II" in the district of Tarapoto - San Martin Province, San Martín state. She is 38 years old and a single mother of 2 daughters, all of which are already independent and help in the business.

She has been in the telephone service business for several years, offering local, national and international phone calls. The business is located in a well established building that allows her to take care of her customers. She started with a loan from Manuela Ramos, buying a mobile and a regular phone, and then she kept growing and currently provides the service to residents of her community.

She is asking for a loan of $525 to buy more mobile phones, regular phones and phone cards to provide a better service to her customers. She is an independent woman who manages and makes decisions in her business. Manuela says “To be a member of a group of women has helped her to learn more about her rights and to work as a group to be respected.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Francisca Yessenia

texts.es:
En la ciudad de León, la señora Francisca Yessenia R. se dedica a su negocio de venta de accesorios para vehículos como parabrisas, cubiertas de neumáticos, alfombras, antenas, cojines, empaques, entre otros.

Ella se ha dedicado arduamente a su negocio y ha logrado salir adelante manteniendo a su hija que por ser muy pequeña debe de mantener. Ella ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito para la compra de los accesorios y así ofertarlos en su localidad.
texts.en:
Francisca Yessenia R. has a business in the city of León. She sells vehicle accessories such as windshields, tire covers, rugs, antennas, cushions, seals, and others. She has worked arduously at her business. She has been able to get ahead taking care of her daughter, who is very small and needs support. She has come to Ceprodel to ask for a loan to buy the accessories and sell them at her place of business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy vehicle accessories

loans.name: Feliciana Isabel

texts.es:
La señora Feliciana P. se dedica a vender productos derivados del maíz como lo es la chicha la cual la vende en bolsa lista para elaborar el refresco. Este negocio lo tiene desde hace 9 años y gracias a sus esfuerzos ha salido adelante en su negocio.

Hoy en día atraviesa la necesidad de invertir en el negocio por medio de la compra del maíz, las bolsas y la leña y para ello ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito para estas compras y así ofrecerlas a sus clientes en el negocio.
texts.en:
Feliciana P. sells products derived from corn like “chicha” (a cold beverage made from corn). She sells her product in a bag ready to make the soft drink. She has had this business for nine years. Thanks to her efforts, she has gotten ahead in her business. She now needs to invest in her business and buy corn, bags, and wood. She has come to Ceprodel to ask for a loan for these purchases so that she can sell her products to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy corn, bags, and wood

loans.name: Esperanza Maruja

texts.es:
La señora Esperanza Maruja V. Z. tiene 42 años, vive en el distrito del Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella  estudió Secundaria Incompleta,  tiene 1  hijo que dependen económicamente de ella.
Esperanza se dedica a brindar el servicio de Salón de Belleza, cuando inicio con Manuela Ramos no tenía el salón de belleza, se dedicaba a la venta de leña  y de la ganancia de la leña se dedico a estudiar cosmetología  e implementar su pequeño salón de belleza que ahora atiende en su domicilio.
Su primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco Mujeres al Progreso, lo invirtió en la compra de leña y briquetas.
El crédito de 800 soles, lo invertirá en la compra de una máquina de afeitar y un sillón para el salón de belleza.
Esperanza tiene como sueño continuar con su Salón de Belleza, estudiar y así perfeccionar para  crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Esperanza offers beauty salon services. When she started with Manuela Ramos, she did not have the beauty salon. She sold wood. With her earnings from selling wood she studied cosmetology and set up her small beauty salon, which is in her home. She used her first loan of 300 PEN from Banco Mujeres al Progreso to buy wood and briquettes. With the loan for 800 PEN she will buy an electric razor and a chair for her beauty salon. Esperanza’s dream is to continue with her beauty salon, study, and improve so that she can grow as an entrepeneur.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy an electric razor and a chair for her beauty salon

loans.name: Irma Gabina

texts.es:
La señora Irma vive con su pareja el señor Ignacio Ariza quien labora para una constructora en la vecina ciudad de Acuña, Coahuila; ella trabaja para una empresa como operadora desde hace 14 años, demostrando una constancia en su área laboral, pero sobretodo perseverancia, ella al igual que su pareja son personas muy responsables y trabajadores. 
Tiene como familia un proyecto a realizar, tal como es la construcción de una barda en el frente de su casa, para mayor protección del hogar y de la familia, motivo por el cual están tramitando este crédito.
texts.en:
Irma lives with her partner, Ignacio Ariza, who works for a construction company in a neighbor city, Acuña, Coahuila. For 14 years, she has worked for a business as an operator, demonstrating perseverance in her work. She and her partner are very responsible, hard-working people.

As a family, they have a project to complete, which is to construct a wall in the front of their house to better protect their home and family. This is the motive for requesting this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To construct a wall

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
La señora Mercedes B. ha logrado mejorar su condición económica por medio de la venta de frutas y verduras en la ciudad de León. Dichas ventas las ha logrado llevar a cabo gracias al apoyo de Ceprodel porque le ha beneficiado grandemente y por ello ha salido adelante.

Hoy en día espera muy confiadamente en que Ceprodel le brindará el crédito y así será beneficiada para la compra de las frutas y verduras para ofertarlas en su localidad.
texts.en:
Mercedes B. has been able to improve her economic condition by selling fruits and vegetables in the city of León. She has been able to carry out these sales thanks to the support of Ceprodel, which has benefitted her greatly and thus moved her ahead.

Today, she confidently hopes that Ceprodel will offer her a loan that will allow her to buy fruit and vegetables to sell in her area.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Jose Santana

texts.es:
El señor José Santana vive con su esposa la señora María y dos hijos, ella se dedica al hogar y al cuidado de la familia. 
Por su parte el señor José labora para una empresa desde hace 4 años en el departamento de materiales; ellos son una familia unida y por el momento tienen el proyecto de construir una barda en el frente de su vivienda para obtener mayor seguridad, motivo por el cual están tramitando este crédito.
texts.en:
José Santana lives with his wife Maria and two children. She is a housewife and cares for the family.

For 4 years, José has worked for a business in the materials department. They are a united family and at the moment have a project to construct a wall in front of their home to improve their security. This is the motive for requesting this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To construct a wall in front of their home

loans.name: Isaura Margarita

texts.es:
La sñeora Isaura Margarita T. se dedica a su negocio de venta de frutas y verduras en la ciudad de León y es de mucha importancia destacar que es muy visitada por los clientes a los cuales los atiendo muy amablemente al punto que ellos se sienten muy satisfechos con el negocio.
